title: Will Nissan sell more than 15,000 units of the LEAF in the US in 2016?
preds: According to the general news and GJP consensus.
12,107 units before December. The top selling month had 1457 units. http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2011/01/nissan-leaf-sales-figures.html
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Charging stations and charge range still a big concern.
The trend is falling short of 15k units
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Based on sales figures reported by EVNews (http://insideevs.com/monthly-plug-in-sales-scorecard/), the Leaf would need to have 198% sales increase from November to achieve 15,000 units before 12/31. Sales results in 2014 and 2015 for the Nissan Leaf would not support a seasonal impact for December.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

November figures are out and for  2016 YTD 12,107 units have been sold. Not possible to sell 3 000 cars in single remaining month. 
http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2011/01/nissan-leaf-sales-figures.html
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

They need to sell 2893 Leafs in December to hit this target. They sold 1457 in November. 
Forecasting with HoltWinters (no beta or gamma), I get ~0.5% chance of December sales that big. 
They have hit that number before. Wish there was a way to put in 0.3% as a forecast.

http://www.greencarreports.com/news/1107541_plug-in-electric-car-sales-for-nov-volt-soars-prius-prime-arrives "Nissan . . .  sold 1,457 Leafs last month (against 1,054 a year ago) . . .  That puts total Leaf sales for the year through November at 12,107, lower than last year's comparable total and considerably below the 2015 total of 30,200, still a record for any plug-in model.

Based on the sales numbers available here (http://insideevs.com/monthly-plug-in-sales-scorecard/), The Nissan Leaf had sold just over 10k units by 10/31. A quick look at prior years' trends suggests a late spike in sales (of the magnitude required to make up the difference) is unlikely.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

- Sales have been going down. 
- They need to average over 2K per month. 
- No new model is coming out (there is a lot of talk about model fatigue)
- Competition (Chevy and Prius) are coming out with new models end of year.
- New battery pack coming out next year that will increase range past 200 miles (so people will wait).

Sales would have to average more than 2000 cars/month in November and December. It's been over a year since they've hit that kind of number. 
I haven't updated my model, but I'd say <1% chance.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Only two months unknown.  Nov and Dec would both have to be higher than the highest month of sales in 2015 and 2016.  Sales would have to be 150% of October sales.  Very unlikely, but not entirely impossible (+ could be year end closeouts, - 2017 model is largely same as 2016 with actual 2nd gen expected in 2018)

Based on sales figures reported by EVNews (http://insideevs.com/monthly-plug-in-sales-scorecard/), the Leaf would need to have 198% sales increase from November to achieve 15,000 units before 12/31.  Sales results in 2014 and 2015 for the Nissan Leaf would not support a seasonal impact for December.
they might not be able to gift that many away...
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Leaf sold 10,650 through end of october. End of year monthly sales are generally in line with monthly averages.
As of today, Nissan is 4350 units short of 15,000. Given the 2016 trend, it seems highly unlikely.
Low gas prices, better EV competition in market

October was relatively good  - best month all year. Still not impossible to hit 15K but it will take a big surge in the last 2 months.
Too much competition from hybrid, gas prices are low

Nope. Unless they pull off a miracle in the last two months. Sales are down around 28% compared to 2015. http://insideevs.com/monthly-plug-in-sales-scorecard/ https://cleantechnica.com/2016/11/02/us-nissan-leaf-sales-reach-100000/

http://www.autoblog.com/2016/11/01/nissan-leaf-100k-sales-us-report/ " . . .  October proved to be a relatively good month, as the 1,412 Leafs sold represented a 14-percent increase from a year earlier. Through October, though, Leaf sales fell 28 percent from a year earlier to 10,650 units"
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  To sell more than 15,000 units before the end of the year, Nissan will have to sell 2175 per month for Nov & Dec.  I do not see that happening.
The best performance since in consecutive four digits is an improvement of 24%. October, November,December needs to sell around 48% more than the last month September to reach 15000.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Continues to be no reason to suspect a sales spike in Q4
September numbers are in. Used Holt Winters, but should use a better predictor. Odds are at 2%.

Looking at monthly sales data, to reach 15,000 units, Oct, Nov and Dec sales will each have to be almost 60% AHEAD of equivalent months in 2015. Given the average Jan-Sep month has been 30% DOWN y-o-y, it appears that there is next to no chance of this happening.
September's 1316 units offer a glimmer of hope, but sales for Q4 will have to be very brisk to make the target.
A 2017 model with likely 200 mile range will leave the 2016 leaf in a void.  Potential leaf customers will wait for the Tesla Model S, or the 2017 version with a longer range.

Tesla Model 3
Cost proposition with fuel sub $2 for much of the year
Range even with the new battery pack 
Competing cars both gas and hybrid offer more for less to include the chevy cruz with auto shut down/start, the smug among us will opt for these options over the inconvenience of the Leaf.

Yes. the ev market is still increasing, the nissan package is good and still improving and is a lot cheaper than others. the customer tendency is to wait for the new products on the market, which makes it hard for the leaf, to reach their goals.

Did a Time Series analysis, and got this forecast: 
Point Forecast Lo 80 Hi 80 Lo 95 Hi 95 
67 1015.9433 331.50077 1700.386 -30.8212 2062.708 
68 988.2022 153.80807 1822.596 -287.8935 2264.298 
69 960.4611 -19.54805 1940.470 -538.3336 2459.256 
70 932.7201 -191.45944 2056.900 -786.5641 2652.004 
The negative numbers aren't going to happen, but the trend is down. The time series puts it about at 20%, assuming I'm reading it correctly. 
September beat forecast, but not by enough--it needed to be closer to 1700. I'll revise down
Sales were up in 3rdQ, but, almost 2,000 per month required in Q4 seems to be too much of an increase.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

I used Holt Winters exponential smoothing on the data (alpha = 0.1), and it downplayed 2013 and 2014 a bit. It moves the average monthly sales down to 1296, which is still more than we've seen this year in any month.  They'd have to exceed by 0.61 standard deviations four months in a row. 
0.61 sigma for a normal distribution is about 27%. Question is, am I doing my math right? If it's 0.27^4, it's less than a percent (4 in a row). If it's just in aggregate, then it's higher. 
Until I can get my math checked for sure on this, I'm going to weigh heavy towards the <1 percent over the 27% and go 2/3rds that way.

Nissan has sold 7922 Leafs so far this year. They would have to outperform their average by 0.38 standard deviations to beat 15000 this year. That's a 38% chance in naive stats.
The data looks like a mess--I can't see a real pattern in it aside from being down since the incentives were pulled. 38% may be optimistic.
Without strong incentives or a large increase in gas prices 15k will be almost impossible.
Seems the leaf sales have fallen , due to season change (sarcasm) and stiffer competition.

Nissan Leaf selling are decreasing year to year, last year they sold a 10,990 units total and this year they only sells 6,856 units at this point. If we compare the sales of the july 2015 with the sales of july 2016, the sales of the current year decreased about 9.5%.

The Nissan Leaf's max. monthly share of total vehicles sold was 0.09% over the last 12 months.  The highest SAAR over the same period was 18.04M and US sales YTD through July 2016 is 10.1MM.  If I assume the industry was to do 18.04MM SAAR in 2016, that implies another 7.9MM vehicles still to be sold.  Using Nissan Leaf's max. monthly market share of 0.09% implies approx. 7.0k vehicles to be sold, on top of the 6.9k vehicles sold YTD, which puts the total at 13.9k. Over the last three months, SAAR has averaged 17.2MM and Nissan Leaf market share has averaged 0.07%, which would imply even less chance of the Leaf hitting the 15k sales mark.   Also, due to oversupply in gasoline, average prices have been trending lower, which I believe makes consumers less willing to purchase the Leaf I leave the probability at 1% since anything can always happen
July's sales of 1063 is about 408 short of pace needed to reach 15,000, adding around 80 additional sales / month to the rate required to meet the 15,000 objective.

Down 2%.  Adequate time left to raise forecast in the unlikely event that the monthly volume increases.

Nissan Leaf is experiencing a series of difficulties this year:  - US Gas prices went down during 2015 and remained low during the first quarter of 2016; although they rose during the second quarter, and this may translate to an increase in sales (Nissan Leaf sales and US Gas prices have a .59 correlation for the period January 2014 - June 2016). Auto buyers, with these lower prices, might prefer to buy similar alternatives: hybrids such as Chevrolet Volt or Toyota Prius. - Upcoming of similarly priced mass market electric vehicles, Chevrolet Bolt and Tesla Model 3, might be undermining Nissan Leaf's demand. Auto buyers might be waiting for the release of a "better" electric vehicle (both Bolt and Model 3 are supposed to have a 200 mile range, as opposed to the Nissan Leaf's 107 mile range). With the Chevrolet Bolt arriving in late 2016, 15000 Leaf units seem hard to deliver. - ARIMA model gives a Nissan Leaf units point estimates of 11000 - 12000 units by December 2016. - Midyear Nissan Leaf sales have under-performed compared to sales in 2013, 2014, and 2015. For the reasons above, I think there's a small probability (13%) of Nissan selling more than 15000 Leaf units in the US. My estimate will change, of course, if gas prices continue to go up and if the Chevrolet Bolt experiences any delays.
5k sales at half way point, no significant changes to the ageing model which will double its sales in the second half of the year

Updated forecast using last 6 months data: 5793 Nissan Leaf have been sold to date.
http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2011/01/nissan-leaf-sales-figures.html 11 586 cars at the current trend, and recent years have been bad for Leaf sales.
June 2016 sales of 1,096 is about half of the June 2015 sales, and is only about 60% of the rate needed to achieve 15,000 for 2016.

Leaf Sales are trailing behind other major models as of July 4th 2016. The first 6 months of the year have seen ~5000 units sold, so over 1600 units would have to sold a month going forward, a number that has not yet been reached this year for the Leaf. The competition is much higher this year as well, with more options ofr consumers to choose from, making it less likely that this gap will be closed in the coming months.

From 2011 (first full year of full year sales) through 2014, the 2nd half of the year sales ranged from 1.3x to 2.1x the 1st half sales. In 2015 that changed- it was .76 of the first half. First half LEAF sales were 5,793 in 2016, which means in order to reach 15k sales by year end sales in the 2nd half would need to be 1.6x first half (an additional 9,207 sales). This is achievable, however it looks unlikely. Main factors are: 1) Overall U.S. trend favoring hybirds and disfavoring full electrics and 2) competitors' offerings besting Nissan in range as well as matching in price. Lower gas prices have eased the urgency of shopping for full electric and made hybrids more appealing.  Gasoline prices through 2016 look more likely to remain cheap rather than returning to expensive. For Q1 2016 over Q1 2015, fully electric vehicles sales in the U.S was down 8% while plug in hybrid sales were up 48%. The upcoming Tesla Model 3 and 2017 Chevy bolt will be priced about $30k and have a range of 200 miles. The 30 kWh LEAF will have a range of about 155 miles. Nissan is scrambling to reach the 200 mile range mark with its next gen, yet this is playing catch up, not improving on competitor offerings. The Model 3 won't be available until late 2017 with many on the reserve list waiting much longer, however a general sense of improving technology might cause many to find a less than 200 mile range unacceptable and willing to wait for next generation improvements. Less pain at the pump will aid this persuasion.
https://www.yahoo.com/tech/nissan-confirms-next-gen-leaf-135003615.html

LEAF sales are not strong this year. By the end of June, 2016, 5793 units had been sold; by the end of June 2015, almost twice that number (9816) had been sold. A number of factors seem to be contributing to 2016's poor performance: cheap oil (so low prices at the pump reducing the demand for electric cars slightly, especially amongst the mid-range consumers at whom the LEAF is aimed); extremely strong competition from more appealing, domestic brands (Tesla Model S and Chevrolet are both competing effectively); a slightly worn-out model, with an unconvincing update for 2016. Talk of a major upgrade to the LEAF for 2017 makes it even more improbable that sales will improve at the end of 2016. Last year, LEAF sales between July and December accounted for a little less than 7500 sales; the LEAF's performance this year has been down on 2015 consistently; even if it improves, matching 2015's performance in the second half of the year, sales would still not reach 15000. However: a rise in oil prices could, in the very short term, trigger renewed interest in electric vehicles, resulting in a fresh surge of interest in the LEAF.  Hence, a 17% chance at this point, considering poor sales so far, and a relatively poor performance in 2015; but with the proviso that this could go either way, depending on other events.
With only 5,793 sold through June 30th, seems increasingly unlikely.

I analyzed the sales of LEAF published by Inside EVs.  By the end of June 2016, 5,793 LEAFs were sold.  It means Nissan has to sell at least 9,208 units by the end of 2016 in order to exceed the 15,000 mark.  Sales figures since 2011 shows that it is possible as long as Nissan performs at historic best every month for the rest of 2016 (i.e. monthly sales increase 10% to 16% over prior month).  If it performs at historic average or lower, then it will not make the challenge.  So, I give it ⅓ chance of making the challenge. Other factors that make things difficult for Nissan:
- Low gasoline price.
- Competitions - more players chase after a at present small market segment.
- Timing - consumers may be waiting for the next generation of LEAF

WARNING, THIS PREDICTION CONTAINS A STRONG --UNTESTED-- ASSUMPTION OF NORMALITY. CONSUME WITH CARE. With 95% confidence, the monthly sales mean is between 817 and 1114. This means that we expect the sales to fall between 10692 and 12480. The requested target does not lie within this range. We therefore move to a higher confidence range. A 99% confidence (still assuming normality, no growth throughout the year) indicates sales will fall between 10411 and 12760. A quick inspection of the sales figures shows no robust linear trend towards growth over the last 6 months (N = 6, r ~ 0.4 -- not significant) I am therefore confident that Nissan will sell more than 15,000 units of the LEAF with probability <1%. Because a 0% score gives me no logical opportunity to move my prediction, I bound it at 1%. Source: http://insideevs.com/monthly-plug-in-sales-scorecard/

To reach the target of 15,000 LEAF monthly sales will have to grow at average 18%. The geometric mean of monthly sales growth rate in 2016 is 6.7% so far.  The competitive landscape looks dangerous for Nissan. With competitors like Tesla and Ford, Nissan LEAF is unlikely to grow at such pace, at least not in 2016 when no significant upgrade or remodel is introduced to the series. Seeing it from the managerial point of view, I calculated 3 sets of  7-month average growth rate after Nissan took significant sales drop. These are the drops in Jan 15, April 15 and July 15. The figures shows that the management team was able to pump up the sales growth rate to an average of 3.8%, -5.4% and 9.5% respectively for 7 month--far off from the required 18%.

Sales in each month of 2016 so far have been less than the same month in 2015. After May 2015, total sales were 7742 whereas they are 4697 in May 2016. Even if sales in the remaining months of 2016 equal the corresponding months of 2015, the year's total will still be less than 15,000. With oil prices still less than half of what they were in 2014 and unlikely to rise by much, savings in running costs compared to conventional cars are much reduced. Further, prospective buyers of electric cars or those using alternative fuels now have more options, and may even be waiting for the Tesla Model 3, The  Leaf's enhanced range of 107 miles on a full charge remains a deterrent (compared to conventional cars and hybrids). It seems the Leaf's moment may have passed. One can comfortably monitor this question month to month. I'd rather do that than follow any more commodities or currencies.

a) Sales through May 2016 are under 4700 units vs. 7700 same period 2015. The rest of the year could match last year's and total would be under 15K.
b) Some crude statistics, average monthly sales for past 17 months = 1292 units, st.dev 400 units. Average required for next 7 months is 1472 units, or 180 above average. Std error for the average across 7 months is ~150 units (400/sqrt(7)), so the next 7 months would need to be a little over 1 std error above average, at ~11% probability on a normal distribution.
c) 11% is probably an overstatement because the monthly sales really aren't independent, and there is a visible downward trend emerging.

Not my area of expertise, by any means, but there's some pretty stark evidence out there suggesting that sales will struggle in the short-medium term. Sales on a month-by-month basis have consistently failed to match 2015 stats (down 39% so far this year) and the looming prospect of a gee-whiz Tesla Model 3 may be deterring many would-be-buyers. http://www.forbes.com/sites/brookecrothers/2016/06/05/the-tesla-model-3-effect-nissan-leaf-first-victim/#1271be265dc4
